Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ Denver

Call to action! (post shared from Black Lives Matter 5280) Facebook page):

BOULDER → Your officials are spreading fear and misinformation about SB 21-62, a jail depopulation bill working its way through the state legislature - don't let them get away with it! Demand that your local officials be publicly supportive of SB 21-62. Let the the DA, Police Chief, Sheriff and City Council know that you need them to support SB 21-62 publicly, and that you see
the misinformation circ...ulating that the Boulder community doesn’t support jail depopulation.

Make sure they hear you loud & clear!

Suggested text (please include details about why this legislation matters to you!):

"Hello, my name is NAME and I live in Boulder. I am writing to ask that Boulder officials publicly express support for Senate Bill 21-62 to depopulate jails in Colorado. Our community needs to be loud and clear that we support this effort to bring our neighbors home! I hope you will make a clear public statement in support of Senate Bill 21-62."

Boulder DA Michael Dougherty
boulder.da@bouldercounty.org
Boulder Police Chief Maris Herold
https://bouldercolorado.formstack.com/for…/contact_the_chief
Boulder Sheriff Joe Pelle
bcso@bouldercounty.org
Boulder City Council members
council@bouldercolorado.gov

Let us know in the comments if you've e-mailed, called, made public comments, or otherwise reached out. <3

See MoreKatie Kelly

#BOULDER, we need to gather our people. This time, they've wandered all the way to the state capitol to oppose jail depopulation and ending wealth-based detenti...on. Yes, Boulder people -- including our police chief -- are writing and organizing and pressuring lawmakers NOT to pass a bill rooted in equity in policing and detention.

*Skeletor voice* STOP THEM

>>> Please write to council and be the opposing force that balances out the fear-filled pressure from Boulder's leaders on this issue: council@bouldercolorado.gov
<<<

Here are some talking points you can work with:
- Why are city leaders opposing the jail depopulation bill at the statehouse?
- Jail depopulation does NOT correlate with increased crime - counties who depopulated saw both increases AND decreases in crime
- Boulder will not be more safe by caging people who have not been convicted of a crime yet
- SB21-62 addresses wealth-based detention for people accused of low-level crimes
- Keeping people in jail pre-trial who are not dangerous wastes millions of dollars
- City leaders should stop opposing a bill that will do nothing to make Boulder safer
- Property crimes and public safety in Boulder should be addressed through city investment

✔Myths: acluco.org/SB62-FAQ
✔Fact sheet: acluco.org/SB62-Facts
✔Pre-trial death stories: acluco.org/SB62-Story

Please write!! And share this with other Boulder folks thx

item.content:encoded:
Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ Denver

Edna is selling flautas & tacos dorados next weekend! She’s raising money to hire a lawyer for her son’s immigration case once it gets closer to his court date. You can support here: https://solidaritymeals.paperform.co. Unlike in criminal proceedings, people in immigration court have no right to a lawyer, and so anyone who cannot afford one must represent themselves. There are some local stopgap programs, such as the Rocky Mountain Immigrant Advocacy Network, which provides ...free legal services to people in immigrant detention, and the Denver Immigrant Legal Services Fund, which pays immigration attorneys to represent people who would otherwise be unable to obtain a lawyer (disappointingly, the Aurora City Council recently voted not to establish a similar immigrant legal defense fund). Our goal is to create a world where immigration courts don’t exist at all, but while they’re here, we will demand for and help fund legal representation for everyone we can.

#solidaritymeals #sanctuary4all #abolishice #abolishprisons #mutualaid

See MoreSanctuary4All Colorado is in Denver, Colorado.

item.title: CALL TO ACTION!: SUPPORT SENATE BILL 62 FOR JAIL DEPOPULATION BY...
item.content:encoded:
Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ Denver

CALL TO ACTION!:
SUPPORT SENATE BILL 62 FOR JAIL DEPOPULATION BY THURS MARCH 4TH!
Call to action source: Elisabeth Epps of the Colorado Freedom Fund (https://twitter.com/elisabeth)

This bill which is similar to policies already in place in many CO counties, authorizes peace officers:...
- To issue a court summons in lieu of making an arrest
- Limits the offenses that may result in arrest
- Decreases the use of cash bonds
- Empowers sheriffs to continue to safely depopulate county jails

Bill text: https://leg.colorado.gov/bills/sb21-062;
Bill summary from ACLU: https://acluco-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/…/SB21-62-Jail-Popul…
Testify (remotely, in person, written): https://www2.leg.state.co.us/…/CLIC…/commsumm.nsf/signIn.xsp

This is a critical step forward given the disproportionate criminalization and jailing of BIPOC and unhoused neighbors.

Email support messages to Senate Judiciary Committee members
You could email them individually, one by one, and/or email them directly if they’re your State Senate and make sure they know that you’re a constituent.

“Hello, my name is NAME. I hope you’ll vote YES tomorrow on Senate Bill 62 when it’s heard in the Senate Judiciary Committee. I support decreasing the use of cash bonds and empowering sheriffs to continue to safely depopulate county jails. I think this is important for our state to take action to support justice for members of our community and bring our neighbors home!”

If you can, please include any personal details about what this bill would mean to you if it passes, how bringing our neighbors home would keep us all safer, and anything else about your own experience or story - those details make a difference!

item.content:encoded:
Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ Denver

Black Lives Matter 5280 and Denver Alliance for Street Health Response urge constituents to join in opposition to HB21-1030, which is being heard in committee in the next two hours! Dr. Apryl Alexander will be sharing proposed amendments during testimony. You can:

Testify in committee or submit written testimony: https://www2.leg.state.co.us/…/CLIC…/commsumm.nsf/signIn.xsp

Contact members of the HHS committee: ...
-dafna.michaelson.jenet.house@state.co.us
lisa.cutter.house@state.co.us
emily.sirota.house@state.co.us
serena.gonzales-gutierrez.house@state.co.us
Iman.Jodeh.house@state.co.us
David.Ortiz.house@state.co.us
Naquetta.Ricks.house@state.co.us
mary.young.house@state.co.us

DASHR's demands:
- Funding being open to entities that are not strictly law enforcement. If this bill is to support community partnerships, then funding must be open to the actual community partners.
- Equal or majority funding going towards non-police models versus co-responder models. There should be a distinction between the two as they are not the same and while there has been some positive impact from co-responder programs, we have heard from social workers that they are often inhibited from doing their jobs by the commanding presence of law enforcement.
- Remove the required $2 million set aside for law enforcement mental health as that would leave almost nothing for crisis response programs.
- Finally, if legislators are to work to support local programs that are community partnerships, then there should be more due diligence in engaging with the municipalities and community organizations doing the work before moving this bill forward in any form.

Let's make sure this bill doesn't make it out of committee in this form! Respond w/a comment if you wrote in, testified online, or submitted written testimony!

See MoreDenver Alliance for Street Health Response

URGENT ACTION ALERT!

Today, HB 21-1030, the Expanding Peace Officers Mental Health Grant Program will receive public hearing in the House Public Health Committe...e at 1:30pm. While this bill positions itself to fund programs like what we've been working on with multiple cities across Colorado and even across the country, the funding is restricted to law enforcement agencies and there is other language that would further harm our efforts. Taking Denver and Aurora for example, two cities we've worked with that have either launched or approved non-police models, neither city would theoretically be eligible for this funding for non-police models. Denver's STAR lives under Denver Department of Public Health and Environment and Aurora's program will live under a director position at the municipal level, outside of the police department. If these two programs are influencing this legislation, then the bill has fallen short of even supporting those cities, as well as others as there is tremendous nuance to each city we've worked to create programs with.

We ask our supporters and community to join us in opposing this bill as it has been written and invite folks to testify. You can do so virtually by signing up at https://www2.leg.state.co.us/…/CLIC…/commsumm.nsf/signIn.xsp. At the very least, we ask that folks submit written testimony or contact their elected officials with the following demands:

- Funding being open to entities that are not strictly law enforcement. If this bill is to support community partnerships, then funding must be open to the actual community partners.

- Equal or majority funding going towards non-police models versus co-responder models. There should be a distinction between the two as they are not the same and while there has been some positive impact from co-responder programs, we have heard from social workers that they are often inhibited from doing their jobs by the commanding presence of law enforcement.

- Remove the required $2 million set aside for law enforcement mental health as that would leave almost nothing for crisis response programs.

- Finally, if legislators are to work to support local programs that are community partnerships, then there should be more due diligence in engaging with the municipalities and community organizations doing the work before moving this bill forward in any form.

We believe that the state should help municipalities work to create non-police models that we've been working on, especially as cities have continued to note funding as a barrier. However, we reject the limited confines of this particular bill and insist on more engagement from those working to introduce it.

item.title: Important update on the Elijah McClain case: **Trigger Warning:...
item.content:encoded:
Showing Up for Racial Justice - SURJ Denver

Important update on the Elijah McClain case:

**Trigger Warning: some of the following includes language describing bodily harm**

The full report of the independent investigation into the Aurora police killing of Elijah McClain was released yesterday. We are posting the link to the report here for the general public’s review. To briefly summarize, it finds that upon review the evidence shows that:

...

1) Officers DID NOT have sufficient reason/cause to STOP Elijah McClain;
2) Officers DID NOT have sufficient reason/cause to FRISK Elijah McClain;
3) There was NOT SUFFICIENT CAUSE to support the PHYSICAL RESTRAINT of Elijah McClain;
4) The DECISION TO APPLY FORCE IN RESPONSE TO THE THREAT OR PERCEIVED THREAT that Elijah McClain reached for an officer’s gun during the struggle is NOT SUPPORTED BY THE EVIDENCE;
5) The record DOES NOT PROVIDE EVIDENCE of the officers’ perception of a threat that would justify consecutive carotid holds, which caused Elijah McClain to either partially or fully lose consciousness;
6) Officers’ assertions of the necessity of pain compliance techniques are IN CONTRAST to Elijah McClain’s audible statements while being restrained;
7) Aurora EMS DID NOT RENDER AID to Elijah McClain for several minutes after arrival and the body worn camera footage DOES NOT REFLECT any attempt by Aurora Fire to examine or question Elijah McClain before the administration of ketamine;
8.)THE DECISION TO ADMINISTER KETAMINE was made within 6 minutes of arrival when Aurora Fire deferred to the recommendation of officers WITHOUT MEANINGFUL OBSERVATION OR DIAGNOSTIC EXAMINATION;
9) Aurora EMS determined it was appropriate to administer ketamine to Elijah McClain despite the fact that HE DID NOT APPEAR TO BE OFFERING MEANINGFUL RESISTANCE in the presence of EMS personnel;
10) THE AMOUNT OF KETAMINE ADMINISTERED was based on a grossly inaccurate and inflated estimate of Elijah McClain’s weight, carrying a higher risk of sedation complications;
11) The Aurora PD’s AFTER-INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS revealed SIGNIFICANT WEAKNESSES IN THE DEPARTMENT’S ACCOUNTABILITY SYSTEMS, with investigative questioning that appeared designed to elicit specific exonerating “magic language” found in court rulings.
https://www.auroragov.org/…/Investigation%20Report%20and%20…
